headline.main: Week in Review: Rate-Rigging Scandal Keeps Growing

docs.abstract: The rate inquiry escalated. | Chinese companies shopped abroad. | The Deal Professor called for the S.E.C. to re-examine old regulations. | DealBook's special section examined business between worlds. | HSBC agreed to pay nearly $2 billion to settle charges over money laundering.

headline.main: Guilty Plea Expected for UBS Unit in Rate-Rigging Case

docs.abstract: The Japanese unit of UBS is expected to plead guilty to a criminal charge in the investigation into rate rigging. | The delay in SolarCity's I.P.O. didn't dissuade investors on the company's first day of trading. | Yahoo continues its effort to remake itself, adding a co-founder of PayPal to its board. | Richard Perry, the hedge fund manager whose firm took a majority stake in Barneys New York, lives in style.

docs.lead_paragraph: Representatives Trey Gowdy and Tim Scott, Republican freshmen from South Carolina, each say the other is the better choice for appointment to replace Senator Jim DeMint.

headline.seo: Trey Gowdy and Tim Scott, Senate Aspirants and Friendliest of Rivals
headline.main: Hoping for a Senate Seat, the Friendliest of Rivals
headline.print_headline: Hoping for a Senate Seat, the Friendliest of Rivals

docs.abstract: South Carolina Reps Trey Gowdy and Tim Scott, first-term Republicans, are contenders to fill seat vacated by retiring Sen Jim DeMint; in friendliest of rivalries, each says the other is the better choice for appointment, to be made by Gov Nikki Haley.
docs.snippet: Representatives Trey Gowdy and Tim Scott, Republican freshmen from South Carolina, each say the other is the better choice for appointment to replace Senator Jim DeMint.

docs.lead_paragraph: Et tu, Michigan? Its unions aren’t powerless, but their influence is waning.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by history and sociology professor Thomas J Sugrue observes that legislation signed by MIchigan Gov Rick Snyder preventing unions from forcing workers to pay dues is latest in series of setbacks for organized labor in the state; contends that declining influence of unions in Michigan has been going on for long time.
docs.snippet: Et tu, Michigan? Its unions aren’t powerless, but their influence is waning.

headline.main: New Life for the Class Act?

docs.abstract: Some advocates for the elderly hope that movement toward national long-term care insurance can be revived.
docs.snippet: Some advocates for the elderly hope that movement toward national long-term care insurance can be revived.

docs.lead_paragraph: While in the hospital for a kidney infection, Tolentino Gonzalez discovered he did not have insurance through his union despite working 75 hours every two weeks.

headline.seo: Denied Insurance, Then Facing a Spiral of Depression
headline.main: Denied Insurance, Then Facing a Spiral of Depression
headline.print_headline: Denied Insurance, Then Facing a Spiral of Depression

docs.abstract: Catholic Charities and Catholic Foundation for Brooklyn and Queens help Tolentino Gonzalez of Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, who suffers from depression, pay his rent.
docs.snippet: While in the hospital for a kidney infection, Tolentino Gonzalez discovered he did not have insurance through his union despite working 75 hours every two weeks.

headline.main: 17 Things I Learned From Reading Every Last Word of The Economist’s “The World in 2013” Issue

docs.abstract: I've been telling people I read The Economist since college. But like many people in Washington, I am a complete fraud.
docs.snippet: I've been telling people I read The Economist since college. But like many people in Washington, I am a complete fraud.

docs.abstract: A look at more than 30 social initiatives covered in Fixes this year shows that working to improve and save lives is still a growth industry.
